At the U.S. border fence with Mexico, just outside of Nogales, Arizona, handprints are left on the iron posts when people try and scale the wall to get into the U.S. These prints are everywhere, and they go right to the top. Border patrol agents said they can often identify people who have just illegally climbed the fence by the telltale rust stains on their hands and clothing.
.
This is part of an ongoing reporting trip for the PBS NewsHour about the border, including the challenges of scaling up border operations under the Trump administration, how local communities are responding to these border protections and how new infrastructure might impact local wildlife. Photo by @wbrangham. .
#photooftheday #border #immigration #handprint #arizona
Producer @jongerberg films along the border wall with Mexico in Nogales, Arizona. Photo by @wbrangham #insidenewshour

President Donald Trump surprised visitors to the White House on Tuesday during the building’s official reopening for public tours. The president and first lady Melania Trump made the announcement in a statement released earlier in the day.
.
According to a pool report, a group of nearly 100, made up mostly of fifth-grade students from Birmingham, Alabama, saw President Trump pop out from behind a partition in the White House’s East Wing. The president called on the tourists to join him on the other side of the roped-off area. One of the tourists—10-year-old Jack Cornish from Birmingham—came over and hugged the president.
.
Tuesday marked the first day of public tours at the 217-year-old White House since Inauguration Day, the Associated Press reported. According to the Washington Post, the White House Visitors Office usually ends public tours during presidential transitions while a new administration puts staff and logistics in place to manage them. Members of Congress—whose offices handle White House tour requests from constituents—inquired when tours would resume after the drought reached three weeks.
.
Interestingly enough, the president stood near a portrait of Hillary Clinton during his appearance this morning.
.
Photo by Jim Watson/AFP/Getty Images. #photography #photooftheday #whitehouse #trump #potus

As polarized politics continue to rage in the Beltway, rural Virginia still has a place where Democrats, Republicans — and some Whigs — stand shoulder to shoulder. The busts of the first 43 U.S. presidents, each standing at least 15 feet tall and weighing nearly 10 tons, are huddled on the property of a local developer who saved them from destruction. Sherriff Sally Hernandez of Travis County, TX has set off a political firestorm by limiting her office’s cooperation with Federal immigration officers (ICE). She says if her deputies are seen as quasi-ICE agents, they can’t do their job of keeping the community safe. “We…need the cooperation of our communities of color. We need them to be running to us, not running away from us.” Texas’ Governor wants her actions outlawed, and many criticize her as “Sanctuary Sally.” Our story on the sanctuary city fight in Texas airs tonight on the PBS @newshour #insidenewshour

#insidenewshour
#Repost from @wbrangham: @newshour's Lisa Desjardins questioning the president on what he's going to do about #DACA -- President Obama's program granting legal protections to young immigrant children brought illegally to the US when they were young.

Our photo of the day: A woman trying to take her children to school is refused passage due to a police blockade Feb. 16 in front of Wat Dhammakaya temple, just north of Bangkok. Soldiers and police surrounded the Buddhist temple on Bangkok’s outskirts early Thursday, in apparent preparation for a raid to arrest an influential monk. The forces surrounded the temple after Thailand’s junta leader invoked special powers to put the site under military control. The temple is among few institutions in the country that have defied the junta leader since a coup in 2014.

Photo by Illian Suwanrumpha/AFP/Getty Images

#thailand #bangkok #photooftheday

My heart is broken over the loss of my beloved friend and PBS NewsHour partner #GwenIfill. She personified courage and the best in journalism; was a joyous gift to all who knew her, and to the millions who knew her through television. May she rest in peace.

Gwen Ifill was the recipient of many accolades during her decades long career in journalism. The most recent high honor she received was the 2016 John Chancellor Award, a ceremony that was set to be held this evening.  Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism honored Gwen today with this image printed in The Washington Post.​ @columbiajournalism
Remembering Gwen Ifill. Share your thoughts and memories about Gwen via the link in our bio. We’ll collect them to be shared with her family and friends.

It is with extremely heavy hearts that we share that our dear friend and beloved colleague Gwen Ifill has passed away. She was surrounded by loving family and many friends whom we ask that you keep in your thoughts and prayers.

A young Turtle Mountain girl adjusts a shirt honoring her dead brother, C.J. Strong Bear Boy Hawk, who died this winter in a car accident on the way to work. The Turtle Mountain tribe sent eight truckloads of firewood to the protest against the Dakota Access pipeline on the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota. "There's been an awakening," says Guy Jones, a member of Standing Rock tribe, as he sits with his family at the main protest camp in North Dakota. They've gathered to try and stop a major oil pipeline from being built under the Missouri River that they argue will not only desecrate ancestral lands, but could potentially leak oil directly into their water supply. Jones says he's never seen a greater assembly of Native people from across the U.S. coming together. (Photo/caption by @wbrangham)

Protesters gather to demonstrate against the Energy Transfer Partners' Dakota Access oil pipeline on the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation. A U.S. District Court judge denied the tribe's request to halt construction of the pipeline Friday. (Photo by @mikewfritz)

Most twenty-somethings spend their formative years between classes and exams, expanding their knowledge. Chico Tillmon spent his 20s, and 30s, in prison. At the age of 23, the gang life had caught up with him.

Tonight on @NewsHour, we talk with Tillmon and others about how to tackle Chicago's escalating violence." Photo by Kenya Downs of Newshour (@LiveFromKenya)

The newest female Marines line up in their squad bay for final inspection. This is the last thing before graduation from Marine Corps boot camp at Parris Island, SC. We're here reporting for @newshour on the young women who are entering the Marines today hoping to go into newly opened frontline combat positions. Radi Saad volunteers with the Syrian Civil Defense, nicknamed the "White Helmets," a group of ordinary Syrian men and women who rush towards the scene of a bombing to save victims. The work they do can be tragic, and is often dangerous. Sometimes, in what's called a "double tap," planes circle back after an original strike to target rescue workers racing to the scene. Here, Saad is pictured  at the funeral of his friend, Issam Al Saleh. The White Helmets say he was killed in a double tap strike by Russian jets in October 2015. 
Watch Special Correspondent Marcia Biggs'  report on the White Helmets on tonight's PBS NewsHour and online (link in our bio).

#Repost from @nscience: "Ever wonder what 10,400 year old sloth poop looks like? Wonder no longer. 
Today, we went behind the scenes at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (@smithsoniannmnh) to check out their massive fossil collection. 
These specimens of ground sloth dung were collected in Rampart Cave, Arizona over half a century ago. In 1976, vandals broke into the cave and started a fire that destroyed 70% of the dung deposits. As a result, these samples are some of the most precious pieces of sloth poop on the planet.

Tune in Wednesday for a @newshour FB Live about dolphin fossils. 🐬🐬🐬"

In Suwalki, Poland, the Second Cavalry Regiment parked its Strykers in the town square and invited Polish children to play and get comfortable with American guns.
.
Tension between Russia and the West hasn’t been this high in a generation. And it’s being taught by both sides to the next generation.
.
“That's where the trust starts. From that youngest generation building trust,” said Lt. Col. Deric Holbrook, commander of the Second Cavalry’s Field Artillery Squadron. “They understand that America is aligned with Poland."
.
@nickschifrin and @zachfannin report from eastern Europe all week, beginning on Tuesday. Their reporting is made possible by the @pulitzercenter #pulitzercenter.

#Repost

Part of the military exercise Anakonda -- considered the largest exercise in eastern Europe since the Cold War -- was flying the American flag in small Polish towns.
.
The United States is popular in Suwalki, which is in the middle of a 60-mile-wide gap where NATO’s notion of collective self defense might be most vulnerable.
.
Just west of Suwalki is Kaliningrad, a Russian enclave; to the east is Belarus, a Russian ally.
.
“Poland [is] vulnerable, absolutely,” one resident told me. “And we need to have some sort of alliance. We need to have American presence.”
.
@nickschifrin and @zachfannin. report from eastern Europe all week, beginning tomorrow. Their reporting is made possible by the @pulitzercenter #pulitzercenter.

#Repost

In Horlivka, deep inside the self-declared Donetsk People's Republic, Soviet-era youth squads are making a revival. Teenage girls spend their Saturday afternoons walking through the town square recruiting 18- to 65-year-old men (and only men) into the Donetsk military. They wear Russian uniforms and ribbons that commemorate Soviet soldiers who died fighting Nazi Germany. "I can't serve," says 15-year-old Katerina (second from the left), "so this is how I can make a contribution." Photo/caption by @nickschifrin, with @zachfannin and @_airbag. This @NewsHour series from eastern Europe airs all week beginning on Tuesday.

Jorge Amaro, an LGBT Latino, leaves a note at the makeshift memorial for the #OrlandoShooting victims in downtown Orlando. Nancy Rosado was set to attend Latin night at #Pulse nightclub the same night 49 people were shot and killed. While she considers herself blessed, Rosado is already a survivor. She's a former sergeant with the NYPD and was there as the Twin Towers collapsed on Sept. 11, 2001. 
She knows first-hand the trauma #OrlandoShooting victims and their families are experiencing. Nearly half of the victims were Puerto Rican. So as vice president of Misión Boricua (Puerto Rican Mission), Rosado wants to make sure what she calls "cultural competency" isn't lost in the aftermath of tragedy. Together with other Latino community members, called Somos Orlando (We are Orlando), she is working around the clock to provide mental health support and resources.
#OrlandoStrong #PrayForOrlando

Name: Judy Woodruff

Job: Co-Anchor and Managing Editor of the PBS NewsHour

What time do you get up? I wake up at 6:30 AM and already feel like it’s late.

How many times do you snooze? Never. If I don’t get up immediately then I know I won’t.

3 things you can't live without in the AM? Toothpaste, NPR’s Morning Edition and the newspaper, which I have to fight my husband for (Al Hunt, also a journalist). If there was a fourth thing, it would be email!

Favorite line from theSkimm recently? "If you believe in something you gotta fight for it." - Golden State Warriors on the fight to keep PB&Js on their private planes. 
What's your morning drink? An iced skim latte.

Who do you let speak to you before coffee? My husband. He can understand me even when I’m half asleep.

As the East Coast recovers from #blizzard2016, a look to the past at an even more mammoth blizzard. The infamous “Knickerbocker Blizzard” of 1922 dumped 28 inches of snow on Washington, D.C. — a record that still stands today. Despite the storm’s ferocity, some residents were able to get out and enjoy the winter wonderland, as seen in photos from the era collected by the Library of Congress.

D.C. residents brave the winter storm to capture the U.S. Capitol in Washington. Visit pbs.org/newshour for more.

Photo by Josh Barajas/NewsHour

#HappyHolidays from Pluto! Err, kind of. On Thursday morning, @nasa released a new image of Pluto decked out for the holidays in a festive green and red coloring. 
While red and green may suit the dwarf planet, the holiday dressing is displaying false color — or wavelengths not visible to the human eye — brought to life using three infrared wavelength ranges that were placed into red, green and blue color channels.

Sangomas, or South African traditional healers, carry forward a long history of healing in the Zulu, Swazi, Xhosa and Ndebele traditions of South Africa. 
Chris Ntombemhlophe Reid, the first white sangoma of the Pondoland region, gave photojournalist Corinna Kern permission to document the practice of training his new students, who are known as thwasas. In this week’s edition of #Parallax, Kern gives an account of part of one thwasa’s initiation with Ntombemhlophe Reid. 
Read the full story at bit.ly/pbsparallax

At the age of 21, Keila was raped by a childhood friend, according to her case. Two days later, she confronted him about what he had done and when he taunted her, she killed him. After the trial, Keila was convicted of murder and sentenced to 15 years to life. In prison, Keila learned how to operate heavy machinery and power tools. She worked for several years on maintenance crews and later in the prison kitchen where she learned culinary skills. In addition, she counseled teens whose mothers were in prison. Photo and caption by Sara Bennett 
People are more than their worst act. That’s the founding principle for an ongoing photography project by Sara Bennett, a former attorney documenting the stories of four convicted murderers working to rebuild their lives. 
See the rest of Sara’s photos at pbs.org/newshour/art

This just in from @NASA: Mars has flowing rivers of briny water. Planetary scientists have now detected hydrated salts on slopes at Hale crater, corroborating their original hypothesis that the streaks are indeed formed by liquid water. The blue color seen upslope of the dark streaks are thought not to be related to their formation, but instead are from the presence of the mineral pyroxene. (📷: @nasa/JPL/University of Arizona)

"My family and friends sometimes forget that I have it, they’ll forget that I wake up every morning with my back hurting. It doesn’t register in their heads. It’s not their fault, I dont complain constantly about it so its easier to forget I have it. I also work as a waitress so a lot of times I’m viewed as weak because I choose not to carry heavy trays. I physically can’t and I have to remind people. I think in their heads they think I’m lazy or making it up. If I could choose to be stronger, I would love to be stronger.” – Vivian. Two brothers created Refunite, a global database aimed at helping to reconnect refugee families torn apart due to conflict or disaster. The nonprofit has worked with several international aid organizations to train local refugees on the technology. 
Training refugees to be outreach volunteers “gives them not just the opportunity to reconnect their community members with missing families but it gives them a strong sense of purpose and work to do,” - Refunite co-founder Christopher Mikkelsen. More: http://to.pbs.org/1EyOp2y

Ocean surface waters are now 30 percent more acidic than they were 200 years ago, largely the result of people burning fossil fuels. Scott Shafer of @KQEDofficial in San Francisco reports for @NewsHour on how acidification is affecting ocean life in the Bay Area.

Keisha Henry and her family opened Cafe Dauphine, the only high-end restaurant in New Orleans Lower 9th Ward since Hurricane Katrina.

Despite $500 million being spent to revitalize the neighborhood, the Lower 9th Ward is still struggling with crime, ruined streets, and hundreds of vacant, storm-damaged homes. While Henry welcomes anyone who wants to move to the Lower 9th Ward and put down roots, she’s wary of the intentions of some would-be “saviors” who’ve come to town. “My family has been in this neighborhood almost 90 years and it is offensive to hear ‘Oh I bought (here) because I want to save you all.” You can hear hers and other survivor’s stories on the PBS NewsHour’s ongoing series on the 10-year anniversary of the storm.  #katrina10yearslater

More of the new homes built in the Lower 9th Ward by Brad Pitt's "Make it Right" Foundation. The foundation has built over 100 of these new, brightly colored, architecturally daring homes in the Lower 9. They’ve all gone to former residents of the neighborhood who lost their homes to Katrina.

The #MakeItRight homes definitely stand out in the neighborhood, which has struggled mightily to rebound from the torrent of water that tore through this area when the flood walls just a few blocks from these homes broke open 10 years ago. The few tidy blocks where the Make It Right homes stand are in sharp contrast to the rest of the neighborhood, which is still blighted with abandoned homes, illegally dumped trashed, and aggressive, fast-moving weeds.  #Katrina10YearsLater
NewsHour’s Mike Melia became a zombie for a day…because journalism. http://to.pbs.org/1KSxSmP
One of the many homes still sitting abandoned in New Orleans’ Lower 9th Ward, ten years after Hurricane Katrina. #Katrina10YearsLater

In many places in New Orleans’ Lower 9th Ward, all that remains of people’s homes are their concrete and brick front steps.  When the flood walls broke open ten years ago, hundreds of houses and hundreds of families were swept away by the floodwaters.  Ten years later, only half the residents of this historically black neighborhood have returned.  This week, @newshour is reporting from New Orleans and the Gulf Coast for the ten year anniversary of the storm. #Katrina10YearsLater

Can the Lower 9th Ward ever bounce back?  A house in New Orleans’ iconic neighborhood struggles to keep its head above the weeds.  It’s estimated that just half of the original residents have returned since the storm.  Watch @maryjobrooks and @wmbrangham’s report about the Lower 9th Ward on @newshour -- part of a week-long series of reports about the ten year anniversary of Katrina. #Katrina10YearsLater

A cinder block foundation is all that remains of a house in New Orleans’ Lower 9th Ward, one of the neighborhoods hit hardest by Hurricane Katrina ten years ago.  Tune in to @Newshour to see @maryjobrooks and @wbrangham's report on the slow pace of recovery in the Lower 9th Ward. #Katrina10YearsLater

Holy Cross neighborhood, Lower 9th Ward, New Orleans. // Ten years after #HurricaneKatrina, it’s still shocking to see these markers on buildings. These X's were spray-painted by search teams to indicate a house had been checked. (The top part of the X showed date searched, right showed hazards inside home, left was which group/agency was searching, bottom was number of people found inside) All this week, @NewsHour is looking at how New Orleans and the Gulf Coast has recovered from Hurricane Katrina.

#Katrina10YearsLater

10 years after #HurricaneKatrina, how safe is New Orleans? @newshour producer/shooter @jongerberg filming some of New Orleans’ new hurricane protections. @jongerberg and @wmbrangham’s report on the safety of the city’s new storm defenses. Link in profile.

#Katrina10YearsLater

“The system that existed around New Orleans prior to Katrina, the hurricane protection system, it was a system in name-only, ” says Col. Rick Hansen of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.

Col. Hansen says New Orleans’ defenses were inadequate and unfinished, and the nation watched in horror ten years ago as Katrina proved that point.

Col. Hansen has been overseeing the $14 billion dollars in improvements made to the city’s hurricane defenses over the last few years, which are featured on @NewsHour’s series of reports, starting tonight on PBS. Link in profile. #Katrina10YearsLater

Is New Orleans safe? Ten years after suffering a near-mortal blow from #HurricaneKatrina, @Newshour returns to the city to examine the state of its current hurricane defenses.  This is one of original flood-walls along the city’s drainage canals that failed so catastrophically ten years ago, flooding over 80% of the city and killing hundreds of people. Photo by @wbrangham #Katrina10YearsLater

Did you know: clams, oysters and mussels are being poached from the Puget Sound and sold for thousands of dollars in a black market. Earth, meet Pluto. 
We thought Pluto would be a cold, dead, lonely place. It turns out to be fascinating, with a lot more features than we thought. It turns out to be a lot more alive than we thought. – NewsHour science correspondent Miles O’Brien. 
New close-up images of a region near #pluto’s equator reveal mountains rising as high as 11,000 feet above the surface of the icy body. Learn more: to.pbs.org/1MuPyag (Photo by @NASA)

#PLUTO

Just before 8 am ET this morning, the New Horizons spacecraft made its closest pass by Pluto — closer than any spacecraft has ever been — a mere 7,800 miles from the surface of the dwarf planet. Considering it’s traveled nine years and more than 3 billion miles to get there, that’s extremely close.

In France, even though the price of books was fixed years ago to prevent price differentiation, some worry the country's thousands of bookstores may now be in jeopardy as more customers flock to online retailers, such as Amazon. The online giant has come under fire by French booksellers who believe the way Amazon sells books is threatening their business and even undermining French culture. For more, watch NewsHour Weekend Saturday or visit pbs.org/newshour.

Photographer and urban explorer @andregovia visited more than 900 locations in 22 countries to capture a lost and abandoned world. In his recently released book, he published 380 of the thousands of photos he took during his adventures in deserted hospitals, schools, theme parks, mansions, cottages, car graveyards and industrial places. For more photos: http://to.pbs.org/17BeI89

“To me, it’s so much about doing your homework … getting access to all different aspects of people’s lives so that I am essentially telling an entire story and not just a single image.” – Photojournalist Lynsey Addario 
From the war in Afghanistan, the Iraq war to the atrocities in Darfur and violence against women in the Congo, @lynseyaddario has been a witness to many conflict zones around the world. See more of her breathtaking work: http://to.pbs.org/1Bni3Fi

In Indonesia & the Philippines, very young children -- as young as four -- work for illegal small-scale gold mining for little money and constant exposure to mercury and cyanide. Pulitzer-winning photojournalist @larrycprice documented the working conditions of some of these gold mines: http://to.pbs.org/17gmYL2

"Climate change is a serious threat to these birds, and equally serious is how we react to climate change." For a number of years, efforts have been made to protect piping plovers. Like many shorebirds, they're already feeling the impacts of rising sea levels. But until recently, their winter habitat was a mystery. 
Watch tonight's PBS NewsHour at 6 p.m. EST online: http://www.pbs.org/newshour/

Celebrations around the world are already underway for the Chinese New Year, which begins next Thursday, Feb. 19 and lasts until March 5. Often marked by fireworks and family feasts within China, customs and observances of 2015′s Year of the Goat vary widely, ranging from traditional festivals to underwater dragon dances. Also known as the Spring Festival, Chinese New Year is widely regarded as the most important celebration in China and is given official public holiday status, during which most Chinese get eight days off of work. See more at pbs.org/newshour. (Photo by Edgar Su/REUTERS.)

Masked revelers have been turning out in style for the Carnival of Venice, a centuries-old festival which began as a way for Venetians to let loose in the days leading up to Lent. Americans live their lives powered by electricity. But even when appliances and devices are powered off — if the devices are plugged in, they’re sucking up power. These so-called "vampire electronics" can add more than $100 to a home’s monthly electric bill, according to the Department of Energy. These are the appliances that suck up the most power, even when they're powered off. For tips on how to stop the phantom power from driving up your electric bill, visit pbs.org/newshour.

Marian Majerowicz (above), 88, was 17 when he was sent to Auschwitz-Birkenau. At the camp he was briefly reunited with his father, who told him that his mother and younger brother were both killed in the gas chambers. Majerowicz’s father didn’t survive the war. 
Tomorrow marks the 70th anniversary of the liberation day of Auschwitz concentration camp. Some of the survivors shared their stories: http://to.pbs.org/1zPdfrp

“He was a true visionary…no one was more passionate about his craft than Mike.” Award-winning film director Mike Nichols, known for such hits as “The Graduate,” “Angels in America,” and “Monty Python’s Spamalot,” died last night. 
His 50-year career, filled with creativity and daring humor, was marked by his skillful ability to jump from the stage to the screen, blurring the lines between genres as he moved. Nichols was 83.
Learn more: http://to.pbs.org/1xuz4K5

Throughout the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, all kinds of things -- batteries, paint, plastic, electronics, even whole vehicles -- were disposed of in so-called “burn pits” by the U.S. military. Some veterans have filed a lawsuit against a defense contractor claiming toxic smoke from burning waste caused lung disease and cancer. Learn more: http://to.pbs.org/1AejuEM (U.S. Air Force photo/Senior Airman Julianne Showalter)

When the Nazis occupied Czechoslovakia in 1939, tens of thousands of Jews applied for visas to anywhere they could. Among them was Paul Strnad and his wife Hedy, a dress designer. Ultimately, neither would get a visa to leave, but 60 years later a descendant discovered Hedy's vibrant designs, and an opportunity to create Hedy's dresses was born. Now, in an exhibit called "Stitching History from the Holocaust," the Jewish Museum of Milwaukee is displaying the dresses Hedy once designed but could never realize, giving viewers "a tangible example of what has been lost in the Holocaust," museum curators said. For more about Hedy's story and to see the designs come to life, visit newshour.pbs.org.

“You think that punk is something maybe urban, but I like the fact that it was anarchy and beauty together.” Every year, on the summer solstice, a special breed of travelers make their way to Stonehenge to watch the sunrise. After years of renovation, the White House Visitor Center is now a modern learning facility that exhibits interactive tools to help you better understand presidential history. From Lincoln’s telegraph key to Franklin D. Roosevelt’s "Fireside chats" desk to a "selfie wall" (included in photo above), more than 90 artifacts from the White House collections are now on display at the visitor center, which opens this Saturday. Summer vacation is over for many students throughout the country, but some schools are in session all year with what's known as a modified or balanced calendar. It has the same number of teaching days as a normal school calendar, but they're spread throughout the year. Proponents say changing the traditional school calendar could boost levels of student achievement. Where do you stand? For more, watch tonight's broadcast of NewsHour Weekend or visit newshour.pbs.org.

After being offered a job as a New York City doorman in 2012, Kevin A. Jones was routinely screened as part of a background check. But soon after, his job offer was revoked when the check turned up a slew of criminal convictions. The only problem was, they belonged to another man with the same name. To see what happened next and to weigh in on whether you think background checks should be used in screening job applicants, visit newshour.pbs.org.

Remember last summer when scientists announced the discovery of a new mammal species called the olinguito? It's a small, furry, tree-dwelling member of the raccoon family that lives in the forests of Colombia and Ecuador. Since then, citizen scientists have been sharing photos they've taken of the animal in the wild. Meet baby olinguito: http://to.pbs.org/1odSslP

The U.S. economy is getting stronger and that’s thanks in part to an increasing number of small businesses and shops that rely on skilled, locally based workers offering hand-crafted products. More than 52,000 unaccompanied children were caught trying to cross the U.S. border in the first five months of this year.

Many of them are fleeing drug violence at home, but here in the U.S, they’re faced with a new set of challenges – a border patrol system unequipped to handle them and a future filled with uncertainty. Watch the full report here: bit.ly/nocountryforkids

A girl rests on a mattress she shares with her five siblings in Nairobi. Female refugees, particularly those without family, are most susceptible to kidnapping and trafficking.

There are about 51.2 million people — half of whom are children — who have been forced to leave their homes, mostly due to conflict. That number of forcibly displaced people is now the largest in the post-World War II era. Photojournalist Amy Toensing (@amytoensing) spent three weeks in Nairobi, Kenya, documenting urban refugee children in the city. For more: http://bit.ly/refugeekids

How do we rebuild urban areas that are prone to flooding, like the shorelines of New York and New Jersey?

That was the question the "Rebuild by Design" competition challenged architects and engineers to answer in collaboration with communities hit by Hurricane Sandy. Take a look at the winners' sustainable proposals to protect NYC's Lower East Side, Hudson River Region, Meadowlands Region, Nassau County, Staten Island and Hunts Point from future floods. http://bit.ly/rebuildbydesign

These girls from Kariobangi slums in Kenya learn boxing for 3 hours everyday. But it's not just a fun pastime for them; it's a way to find a safe community, empowerment and an emotional toolkit for fighting for themselves. 
Kenyan photographer Mia Collis captured the #Boxgirls -- an organization that started because of rapid increase in rape cases in the slums. For the full story: http://to.pbs.org/1rOvd9S

On June 4, 1989, Chinese troops violently retook #TiananmenSquare, firing into the air and directly at crowds of pro-democracy demonstrators who had been occupying the square. An unknown number of protesters were killed, with some estimates in the thousands. Hundreds were wounded. The democratic movement was crushed.

This photo illustrates the days leading up to the massacre.  Hundreds of thousands of student protesters face policemen in the square in April 1989. #todayinhistory

60 years ago this Saturday, the Supreme Court declared school segregation unconstitutional in the case of "Brown v. Board of Education." When Linda Brown -- who can be seen in the photo above from 1953, seated in the second row from the right in her segregated classroom in Topeka, Kansas -- was denied enrollment at a "whites-only" school, her family initiated the now landmark Civil Rights lawsuit. Nearly 50 years ago, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the 1964 Civil Rights Act with Martin Luther King Jr. by his side. The monumental law meant no more segregated schools. No more racially divided restaurants, buses or water fountains. Half a century later, the first black man to become president commemorates what’s been accomplished and recommits the nation to fight inequalities that remain.

President Barack Obama will speak today at the #CivilRightsSummit at the LBJ Library in Austin, Texas. We’ll live stream his speech, schedule for 1 p.m. EDT on our homepage.

“Today we have a reason to celebrate the normal moments of life, that are easy for others to take for granted. If the genocide reveals humanity’s shocking capacity for human cruelty, Rwanda’s choices show its capacity for renewal.” – Paul Kagame, President of Rwanda

Thousands of Rwandans gathered today to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the genocide that shocked the world by taking 800,000 lives in 100 days. The memorial service honored the dead and celebrated how far the country has come.

As residents in Barrow, Alaska fight against changing weather patterns and melting sea ice, many are also determined to keep their traditional ways of life. "Melting Ice, Warming Waters Could Erode Way of Life in Alaska's North Slope," is part of a series of stories on Arctic Climate Change that begin Sept. 16.  #seachange. #NewsHourOnAir #nofilter

“New research suggests the chemistry of the North Pacific is changing in ways that pose serious trouble for Alaska’s two signature crab species, red king crab and snow crab. The culprit: ocean acidification caused by human carbon-dioxide emissions.” The Seattle Times reports as part of a NewsHour climate change in the Arctic series which begins airing Sept. 16. #seachange #NewsHourOnAir

Melting ice in the arctic means ship traffic, including this sailboat in Barrow, Alaska, has become more frequent. PBS NewsHour explores the challenges of more water and more boats and ships headed for it beginning Sept. 16. Photo by NewsHour's Mike Fritz #seachange #nofilter

PBS NewsHour Weekend report: “When I go to the pump, I am filling my car with gas.  I'm not thinking about the taxes I'm paying.  And I'm paying both federal and state. When you get a bill in the mail, you think about the taxes that you're paying.” -Oregon driver

From an upcoming PBS NewsHour Weekend report: “If we the Palestinians don’t take risks then who’s going to do that and our nation will never be built.” Bashar Masri, the Palestinian businessman behind the West Bank’s first planned city. “It’s not about intifada and throwing stones and terrorism. It’s not like that. It’s also that we have our kids. We are educated. We have a future and we aim to have our independent state.” Maher Abu Madi, Rawabi homeownerv.

“Tides are totally predictable, we've known for centuries when the tides are coming and going.  We can tell you on this day, 20 years from now-- at this moment, how much electricity we'll be generating. “ PBS NewsHour Weekend explores an innovative tidal turbine in Downeast Maine.

“A terrible family tragedy occurred here -- a tragedy set in motion dramatic changes to the laws governing drinking and driving in British Columbia. Supporters say these changes have already saved dozens of lives.” PBS NewsHour Weekend Correspondent William Brangham reports from Vancouver.

"When I was a boy and I would see scary things in the news, my mother would say to me, 'Look for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.' To this day, especially in times of 'disaster,' I remember my mother's words, and I am always comforted by realizing that there are still so many helpers -- so many caring people in this world."-Mister Rogers...This 1978 photo by Jim Judkis and touching quote went viral over the weekend.

Instagram responds to the backlash against a new Terms of Service that suggested they could sell user photos to advertisers: “To be clear: it is not our intention to sell your photos. We are working on updated language in the terms to make sure this is clear.”

You've probably seen this little announcement pop up in your newsfeed. Under Instagram's updated Terms of Service agreement, your photos and data may be used for advertisement purposes. Are you concerned? Enough to stop instagramming?
